properties.name: Ariel Lopez
properties.descriptio: Ariel Lopez moved from Chile to the Bay Area in 1994, and has been living in San Francisco�۪s Mission District since 1996. In this interview, he discusses his work in the community, his family, and how the tenants of his building organized to resist e
properties.credit: Interview by Andrew Szeto, Photography by Rebecca Gourevitch

properties.name: Natalia Arguello-Inglis
properties.descriptio: Natalia is a recent Lowell high school graduate, born and raised San Francisco. Currently in her first year at UC Santa Barbara, here she discusses gentrification in San Francisco, and experiences being a youth in a changing city.

properties.name: Nancy Hernandez
properties.descriptio: Nancy is a non-profit worker who was born and raised in the Outer Mission, but has been forced to relocate. Nancy currently lives in Oakland.
properties.credit: Interview by Caroline Scanlon, Natasha Weiss, Jordan Carroll

properties.name: Elvira y Refugio Nieto
properties.descriptio: Elvira y Refugio Nieto, mother and father of Alex Nieto who was killed by the SFPD in March 2014, reflect on the loss of their son.
properties.credit: Eva Mas Silberstein and Marko Muir

properties.name: Lisa Gonzales
properties.descriptio: Lisa Gonzales, along with her daughter, mother, and grandmother, were all being threatened by eviction after Jason Chan of Barbagelata Real Estate condo converted her Mission home and failed to offer her a lifetime lease. With the AEMP, the Tenants Union
properties.credit: Interview and photograph by Samantha Kaplan

properties.name: Martina Ayala
properties.descriptio: Martina Ayala is an artist and cultural worker, and very involved in the Mission Cultural Center and arts community in the Mission. She and her partner were harassed and evicted from their home in the Richmond.
properties.credit: Interviewed by Lucia Constantine.Photographed by Michael Hendrickson.

properties.name: Stewart
properties.descriptio: Stewart is a long-time San Francisco resident and tech worker with AIDS, recently displaced from his apartment.
properties.credit: Interview by Caroline Scanlon, Natasha Weiss, Jordan Carroll

properties.name: Anna Smith
properties.descriptio: Anna Smith was born in Puerto Rico. When she was two-years-old, she moved to Florida. She then returned to Puerto Rico until she was twenty-five, upon which she moved to San Francisco. that’s when she moved to San Francisco three years, ago. Since she

properties.name: Jessica
properties.descriptio: Jessica and her family live in Section 8 housing in San Francisco. Most tenants in the building speak Cantonese and Vietnamese, and so 17-year-old Jessica has become a translator and spokesperson in their fight to remain in their homes. Their building wa

properties.name: Susan Suval
properties.descriptio: Susan was forced out through a combination of Owner Move In and Harassment from her home on the Great Highway, where she had lived since 1980. She relocated in Parkmerced.

properties.name: Paula Tejada
properties.descriptio: Paula Tejeda owns a small empanada shop in the Mission. Originally from Chile by way of New York City, she's lived and worked in the Mission for over ten years. In addition to making empanadas, she has been highly involved in neighborhood activism.

properties.name: Andrew Szeto
properties.descriptio: Andrew Szeto is an Asian American housing rights activist and writer. Born and raised in SF, here he reflects on gentrification has it has impacted him and his community.

properties.name: Jason Wallach and Sandy Juarez
properties.narrative: <iframe src="https://archive.org/embed/SandyJasonFinal" width="640" height="480" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" allowfullscreen></iframe>
properties.descriptio: Jason and Sandy were evicted from 6511 Raymond St. Oakland by Dan Daigle. They had been living there 3 years and 5 months, since they arrived to the Bay Area. An Oakland story was included because few people understand that the epidemic of evictions is w
properties.credit: The original footage was captured on January 17, 2014 as part of a storytelling circle called "Campfire: Eviction Ghost Stories and Other Housing Horrors." This mini-clip is part of a series of mini-clips honoring fourteen City storytellers who shared th

properties.name: Reid Stuart
properties.descriptio: Reid Stuart has lived in his apartment in the Mission for 17 years. He has been threatened with eviction on multiple occasions by his landlord.
properties.credit: Interview by Carly Wais, Photo by Samantha Kaplan

properties.name: Francisco Romano
properties.descriptio: Francisco is a middle-aged gay man with AIDS who makes ends meet with disability payments. He is now counting the days until his eviction. He explains that "San Francisco has changed but I feel it's my home. I have my friends and my medical support here.

properties.name: Evan Wolkenstein
properties.narrative: Anti-Eviction Mapping Project--Evan W. from
properties.descriptio: Evan teaches at the Jewish Community High School in the city, and is currently being evicted by Google's head of e-Discovery, Jack Halprin.

properties.name: Benito Santiago
properties.descriptio: Benito Santiago and his fellow tenants at 151 Duboce Street received their Ellis Act eviction notice in December 2013.  Benito - Filipino, born and raised in SF, a teacher for the Unified School District, and disabled - launched a strong campaign with Ev
properties.credit: Oral history by Manissa Maharawal, Photography by Michael HendricksonThe original footage was captured on January 17, 2014 as part of a storytelling circle called "Campfire: Eviction Ghost Stories and Other Housing Horrors." This mini-clip is part of a s

properties.narrative: <iframe src="https://archive.org/embed/CampfireSarahBrendt" width="640" height="480" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" allowfullscreen></iframe>
properties.descriptio: Sarah Brant is a San Francisco public school teacher and lifelong City dweller, who is currently being Ellis Act evicted fromher Mission District apartment, alongside her 98 year old neighbor, MaryElizabeth (M.E. or Emmy) Phillips. Emmy has lived in her
properties.credit: The original footage was captured on January 17, 2014 as part of a storytelling circle called "Campfire: Eviction Ghost Stories and Other Housing Horrors." This mini-clip is part of a series of mini-clips honoring fourteen City storytellers who shared th

properties.name: Greg Ivanov
properties.descriptio: Greg Ivanov is a Russian immigrant who grew up in San Francisco’s Richmond district. He traveled all over the Bay Area in his recently concluded career as a Ballet dancer. Recently he was evicted from his home on Connecticut Street.

properties.name: Lauren Montana Swiger
properties.narrative: <iframe src="https://archive.org/embed/LaurenSwigerFinal" width="640" height="480" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" allowfullscreen></iframe>
properties.descriptio: Lauren Montana Swiger is an activist, musician, and community member who was evicted from the Mission, along with her teenage daughter. It was an Owner-Move-In eviction, one of three kinds of no-fault evictions displacing San Franciscan families and comm
properties.credit: The original footage was captured on January 17, 2014 as part of a storytelling circle called "Campfire: Eviction Ghost Stories and Other Housing Horrors." This mini-clip is part of a series of mini-clips honoring fourteen City storytellers who shared th

properties.name: Polo Gonzalez
properties.narrative: <iframe src="https://archive.org/embed/PoloFinal" width="640" height="480" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" allowfullscreen></iframe>
properties.descriptio: Polo Gonzalez is a Mission District local. He has been involved in community services since his youth, including graffiti abatement programs, volunteering at event security for Carnival, and most recently, collaborating with the DJ Project at Horizons Un
properties.credit: The original footage was captured on January 17, 2014 as part of a storytelling circle called "Campfire: Eviction Ghost Stories and Other Housing Horrors." This mini-clip is part of a series of mini-clips honoring fourteen City storytellers who shared th

properties.name: Tom Rapp and Patricia Kerman
properties.narrative: <iframe src="https://archive.org/embed/CampfireTRappPKerman" width="640" height="480" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" allowfullscreen></iframe>
properties.descriptio: Patricia Kerman, now a disabled senior citizen, has lived in her current flat for the past 27 years and Tom Rapp has lived there as her roommate for the last 15 of them. They are being Ellis Acted from their home by their landlord Kaushik Dattani.
properties.credit: The original footage was captured on January 17, 2014 as part of a storytelling circle called "Campfire: Eviction Ghost Stories and Other Housing Horrors." This mini-clip is part of a series of mini-clips honoring fourteen City storytellers who shared th

properties.name: Tony Robles
properties.descriptio: Tony Robles is a Filipino activist, poet, and artist, born and raised in San Francisco. He leads the housing fight with Senior and Disability Action, as well as the Manila Town Heritage Foundation. He is co-editor of Poor Magazine.

properties.name: Lotta Garrity
properties.descriptio: Lotta is a senior living at 632 Guerrero who was Ellised last year by serial evictor Sergio Iantorno. She had been a nurse for most of her life and ran a daycare from her unit for 4.5 years, and her husband is a creative map-maker. She tells her current
properties.credit: Interview by Jin Zhu, Edited by Illana Sawyer

properties.name: Ariel Appel, Get Free, AEMP
properties.descriptio: The GET FREE Project talks about the Anti-Eviction Mapping Project with Ariel Appel. Ariel talks about the launch of our oral history project Kick Off event at the Octopus Literary Salon.

properties.name: Rose Egar
properties.descriptio: Rose grew up in the Bronx, and moved to San Francisco in the 1970s, where she met her husband on her second day in the city. After studying philosophy in college, she became a self-taught blues musician. She received an eviction notice in January 2013 wi
properties.credit: Interview and photograph by Samantha Kaplan

properties.name: Anti-Eviction Mapping Project, Betti Ono Gallery
properties.narrative: Oakland Community Power Map from
properties.descriptio: Building our Community Power Map at the Betti Ono Gallery

properties.name: Alexander Beshar
properties.descriptio: Born in China, raised in Japan, and originally from Russia, Alexander Besher is a San Francisco-based writer who has traveled all over and gained a multicultural view of the world. He has moved several times within the Bay Area since first settling here,
properties.credit: Interview and photograph by Manon Vergerio

properties.name: Conor Murphey
properties.descriptio: Conor is a first generation San Franciscan. After attending a school in Southern California, Conor enrolled in the University of San Francisco and pursued a major in Politics, during which he was evicted by his landlords. This interview focuses on Conor

properties.name: Dirk Hoekstra
properties.descriptio: Dirk Hoekstra remembers when he could see across the city without high rises and condos. His building was bought by Urban Green Investments, known as being, "the worst tenant clearing company." After Dirk exhausted his resources battling to keep his home

properties.name: Tom Anderson
properties.descriptio: Tom Anderson grew up in the suburbs outside of New York before moving to San Francisco in the 1990s, at the age of 34. In this interview excerpt, he describes how he has seen the Mission change throughout his 18 years here, from a place where he could ge
properties.credit: Interview and photograph by Samantha Kaplan

properties.name: Michael Rouppet
properties.descriptio: Michael Rouppet lived in a house in the Lower Haight for 20 years before being evicted following the death of his landlady. He spent almost a year living on the street in San Francisco with his dog (the only belonging salvaged from the eviction) and copi
properties.credit: Interview and photograph by Manon Vergerio

properties.name: Dogpaw Carillo
properties.descriptio: Dogpaw Carillo, a San Francisco native, has lived at his apartment in the Mission for 31 years. He was served with a 60 day eviction notice in September because new owners claim the unit he has been living in is "illegal."
properties.credit: Interview and photograph by Samantha Kaplan

properties.name: Serena
properties.descriptio: Serena grew up in the Sunset near the beach. She moved away to go to UC Santa Cruz, and upon returning, found her way to the anarchist collective house, Station 40. At the time of this interview, Station 40 and the multiple tenants that live there, inclu

properties.name: Mira Ingram
properties.descriptio: Mira grew up in Orange County, where she never felt like she quite fit in. As a queer ���punk,�۝ she found very few people she could relate to and moved to San Francisco in search of a more accepting, safe environment. When she first got here, s

properties.name: Tony Longshanks LeTigre
properties.descriptio: Tony Longshanks LeTigre moved to San Francisco in 2009 and has been in love with the city ever since. He has been through the worst of times here and the best of time. He loves the city for what it is all about and through many evictions and homelessness

properties.name: Eddie Stiel
properties.descriptio: Originally from Cleveland, Ohio, Eddie Stiel moved to Oakland from Boston in 1989. In the 1990s, he moved to 22nd and Folsom Street and has lived within a few blocks of 24th Street ever since. Here he offers some encouraging words to anyone facing a poss

properties.name: Joey Vaez
properties.descriptio: Joey Vaez was born and raised in Bernal Heights, where he and his mother still live. Joey was a good friend of Alex Nieto, who was shot and murdered by the SFPD in the context of a gentrifying neighborhood and city. Joey see the murder of Alex, as well a
properties.credit: Interview and Photography by Erin McElroy

properties.name: Vida Kuang
properties.descriptio: Vida Kuang recently graduated college and has returned home to continue living with her parents in their small unit in Chinatown. She reflects on the changes she is witnessing with new eyes as San Francisco caters to wealthier, whiter demographics to who

properties.name: Yasmin
properties.descriptio: Yasmin is a self-employed cook who was recently displaced from her home in San Francisco. Yasmin now lives in Oakland.
properties.credit: Interview by Caroline Scanlon, Natasha Weiss, Jordan Carroll

properties.name: Edwin Lindo
properties.descriptio: Edwin was born in San Francisco’s St. Luke’s Hospital and grew up in his grandmother’s home in Bernal Heights. His grandmother transferred the home to a relative who immediately began trying to evict the family. “I mean 21, 22 years...and I thoug

properties.name: Erica Hruby
properties.descriptio: Erica Hruby is from Boston, Ma but lived in the Lower Haight of San Francisco for 7 ½ years until she, along with her 2 roommates were evicted from their apartment on 371 Hermann street by their landlords, Patrick Waters and Douglas Thorogood along with

properties.name: Jeremy Mykaels
properties.descriptio: Jeremy Mykaels, a disabled senior fighting full blown AIDS received his Ellis Act eviction notice after living at his home in the Castro for 19 years, and in the Casto for 40 years. He was being evicted by 3 speculators from Atherton with a shell company

properties.name: William S
properties.descriptio: William S. is a musician born in Kingsburg, California, who moved to San Francisco to pursue his dream. He has always seen San Francisco as his home and sees the growing change in San Francisco. He has been evicted twice and now lives with his sister and

properties.name: Marie Morales
properties.descriptio: Marie's building sold to new owners in late November 2013. The new owners apparently lost their home in a foreclosure and thus are moving into her home with their family (in addition to raising Marie's rent before doing so). She and her roommate didn�

properties.name: Cheryl SV
properties.descriptio: "When you evict somebody, you're changing their whole lives - it's not just a place where somebody goes and sleeps." Cheryl lived in San Francisco for 30 years, and in her apartment in the Mission for 22 years before being evicted and moving to Oakland.

properties.name: Yasmin
properties.descriptio: Yasmin is a self-employed cook who was recently displaced from her home in San Francisco. Yasmin now lives in Oakland.
properties.credit: Interview by Caroline Scanlon, Natasha Weiss, Jordan Carroll

properties.name: Claudia Tirado
properties.descriptio: Born in Tijuana, Claudia Tirado moved to the United States at age 11. She was born to a mixed race couple, a Chinese father and Mexican mother and fondly remembers the unique characteristics of each culture. She also remembers the challenges of growing u
properties.credit: Interview by Manissa Maharawal, Photograph by Rebecca Gourevitch

properties.name: Neil Martinson
properties.descriptio: Neil Martinson is a DJ and a show producer who grew up in New York's Greenwich Village and moved to San Francisco in the early 1990s. In his interview, he describes what initially drew him to San Francisco, and how this cultural quirkiness is being threa

properties.name: Ben Cady
properties.descriptio: Bed Cady is an artist, born and raised in San Francisco, fighting a massive eviction at 1049 Market Street. Over 70 units are facing displacement as the Twitter Tax Break zone increasingly gentrifies.

properties.name: Rick Gerharter
properties.descriptio: Rick Gerharter is a San Francisco based photojournalist who has documented the queer communities of San Francisco for nearly 25 years. He is regularly published in the Bay Area Reporter of San Francisco and in a wide variety of periodicals, newspapers, b
properties.credit: Interview by Caroline Scanlon, Natasha Weiss, Jordan Carroll, and Zeph Fishlyn

properties.name: Jacqui Naylor
properties.descriptio: Jacqui Naylor is an acclaimed jazz musician who grew up in Saratoga, CA. She moved to San Francisco when she was 18 and studied marketing before starting her musical career. For the past 25 years, she has been living in Hayes Valley with her husband in a
properties.credit: Interview and photograph by Manon Vergerio

properties.name: Elsa Ramos
properties.descriptio: Elsa Ramos is a born-and-raised Mission District resident and undergraduate researcher. She has learned about gentrification from a young age and now sees higher rents and upscale businesses changing the character of the neighborhood which has always rep

properties.name: Steve B.
properties.descriptio: Steve B. moved to San Francisco from the Midwest in the 1980s, joining in with the local punk music and arts scene. In the mid-1990s, changes to rent-control law brought a protracted battle with his landlords over basic rights.
properties.credit: The original footage was captured on January 17, 2014 as part of a storytelling circle called "Campfire: Eviction Ghost Stories and Other Housing Horrors." This mini-clip is part of a series of mini-clips honoring fourteen City storytellers who shared th

properties.name: Carly Wais
properties.descriptio: Carly Wais is an activist from Baltimore, who worked with the Anti-Eviction Mapping Project in San Francisco, collecting oral histories and creating our zine. Here, she reflects on what it is like to be a youth, student, and activist in San Francisco.

properties.name: Fredrick Cloyd
properties.descriptio: Fredrick Douglas Kakinami Cloyd was born in Japan shortly after the U.S. Occupation officially ended. His African-American/Cherokee father was an occupation soldier in Korea and Japan while Fredrick’s mother—a Japanese/Chinese/Austro-Hungarian girl o

properties.name: Ethan Davidson
properties.descriptio: Ethan Davidson grew up in Sausalito and San Francisco, and from an early age was involved in anti-eviction organizing. Here he recounts Sausalito houseboat culture during the 1970s, the I-Hotel movement, the San Francisco punk scene, being evicted in the

properties.name: Marie S.
properties.descriptio: Marie S. was born in Kingsburg, California and moved to San Francisco in 1976. She was a transfer student in Economics at San Francisco State University, who also went to Laney College to do their bakery program. Marie was active in the Nob Hill Associat
properties.credit: Interview in partnership with Kathleen Coll's Urban Politics Class at USF.

properties.name: Rio Yanez
properties.narrative: Rio Interview from
properties.descriptio: Rio Yanez, a Latino Mission artist, is currently being evicted by serial evictor Sergio Iantorno, along with his Mission artist parents, Rene Yanez and Yolanda Lopez. His family has lived in the same apartment on San Jose Ave since 1978.

properties.name: Marla Knight
properties.descriptio: Marla Knight's family has been in San Francisco for four generations and she has been in the same North Beach apartment since 1966. From her bay window over Lombard St., Marla has seen the city change time and time again. This wave of changes, however, h

properties.name: Megan Wilson
properties.descriptio: In this interview excerpt, Megan discusses the shift she has witnessed throughout her 20 years living in San Francisco. She talks about what drew her here in the first place - the close-knit, open community, the sense of resource sharing and connection,

properties.name: Shannon Wirth
properties.descriptio: Shannon lost her home via short sale during the foreclosure crisis, inciting her disillusionment with the "American Dream." She now lives with her mother and son in Fremont, where she grew up, unable to find an affordable rental unit.

properties.name: Z

properties.credit: Interview by Marko Muir. The original footage was captured on January 17, 2014 as part of a storytelling circle called "Campfire: Eviction Ghost Stories and Other Housing Horrors." This mini-clip is part of a series of mini-clips honoring fourteen City s

properties.name: Tiye Silon Shepard
properties.descriptio: Tiye Silon Shepard was born and raised in the Mission District of San Francisco. Her parents moved from the South to San Francisco for work, as many African Americans did in that generation. As a San Francisco native, recent University of San Francisco g

properties.name: Midtown Apartments
properties.narrative: Midtown Call to Action - Call Ed Lee to Stop Midto
properties.descriptio: In 1968, redevelopment forced hundreds of Fillmore residents from their homes. The City established Midtown Apartments for the displaced, they were promised equity ownership. In 2007, tenants paid off the mortgage and the Board of Supervisors made a long

properties.name: Renita Valdez
properties.descriptio: Richard Padilla aka Renita Valdez is currently being OMI evicted by Leslie Wan and Brian Keller. Renita, who has been Grand Empress of SF, says, "I love my house been there along with my niece Jennifer since June 1996. Its walking distance to my job, Saf

properties.name: Jill Vice

properties.name: Candace Roberts
properties.descriptio: Candace Roberts was born in Fremont, California. She came to San Francisco in 2000 for work and lived in a shared apartment in the Mission District. Her passion for singing and producing music made it hard for her to work a 9-5 job and still make enough

properties.name: Cristina Pachano Lauderdale
properties.descriptio: Cristina Pachano Lauderdale is a student and San Francisco resident of four years. She was evicted from her apartment of two years in the summer of 2014 when the owner sold the property. Cristina was given a month to relocate with her three other roommat

properties.name: Erin, Carla, Sam
properties.address: Clarion Alley, SF and Omni, Oakland
properties.descriptio: In this clip Sam Omar-Hall sits down Erin McElroy and Carla Wojczuk at the Omni to talk about the history of the Anti-Eviction Mapping Project, including the recently completed mural project in Clarion Alley and their upcoming project in Alameda County.

properties.name: Michelle L
properties.descriptio: Originally from West Los Angeles, Michelle moved to San Francisco ten years ago for the sense of community and volunteerism. She became heavily involved with the arts community and her work mostly centers around massive, wall stencils. Each year she work

properties.name: Theresa Flandrich
properties.descriptio: Theresa is an activist and active member of the anti-eviction movement in San Francisco, currently fighting an Ellis Act eviction in North Beach.
properties.credit: Interview and film by Alexi Lacey and Jin Zhu. Video of action by Rebecca Gourevitch.

properties.name: Erin, Carla, Sam
properties.address: Clarion Alley, SF and Omni, Oakland
properties.descriptio: In this clip Sam Omar-Hall sits down Erin McElroy and Carla Wojczuk at the Omni to talk about the history of the Anti-Eviction Mapping Project, including the recently completed mural project in Clarion Alley and their upcoming project in Alameda County.

properties.name: Manissa Maharawal
properties.descriptio: Manissa Maharawal is a doctoral candidate in CUNY's anthropology program and an active member of the Anti-Eviction Mapping Project's oral history project too. Here she reflects on how she came to learn about gentrification through childhood experiences i

properties.name: Z

properties.name: Dorothy Santos
properties.descriptio: Dorothy R. Santos is a writer, editor, and curator whose research areas and interests include new media and digital art, augmented reality, online performance, gaming, open source culture, and political aesthetics. Born and raised in San Francisco, Calif

properties.name: Mia Carrasco
properties.descriptio: Mia Carrasco is a third generation native San Franciscan who lives in the Bayview after growing up in the Sunset where her brother was killed by the police. Here she reflects on his death, but also on the gentrification of San Francisco.
properties.credit: Interview by Erin McElroy and Marina Binsack

properties.name: Anonymous
properties.descriptio: __ gives perspective on change and gentrification in her North Oakland neighborhood with unique insights and humor. Hear about why she prefers living in immigrant communities, how the language overheard on her street is changing, commentary on the evolut
properties.credit: Interview by Carly Wais. Editing my Neshma Micropixie.

properties.name: Betty Mackey
properties.descriptio: Betty Mackey was recently evicted from her home on Yerba Buena Island along with over 100 other residents for the city to develop 285 luxury units in their place. Here Betty reflects on what it is like to be newly homeless and uncertain as to where she w

properties.name: Daniel Okada
properties.descriptio: Daniel Okada was evicted from his home in Soma, which he reflects upon here. He was born in the South Bay. He served in the US Army in the 2000s, after which he came back to SF to study animation, where he experienced an OMI eviction.

properties.name: Katherin Canton
properties.descriptio: Raised between The Town (Oakland) and The City (San Francisco), Katherin Canton envisions an arts-centered healthy city to call home. Here she reflects upon growing up in and between the two cities as they gentrify, and what it was like to live in public

properties.name: Alex Oh
properties.descriptio: Alex Oh is a computer science college student at the University of San Francisco whose parents had to sell their house after the 2008 recession, and rising cost of living in San Francisco. Alex’s parents are Korean immigrants who ran a dry cleaning bus

properties.name: The Navarros
properties.descriptio: Here the Navarros reflect on the impending eviction of their Mission Street gym.

properties.name: Ingrid Meyers
properties.descriptio: Ingrid was born in Walnut Creek, and grew up in Berkeley and Vallejo. She lives in Vallejo now, which is home to her despite the violence she encounters there. She lived in SF to go to undergrad, where she made ends meet by living with her boss while doi

properties.descriptio: Michael "Med-O" Whitson and LisaRuth Elliot were flatmates at 1668 Page St. in the Haight. After their building was sold and they initially refused to accept a buy-out settlement, the new owners hired the leading landlord law firm of Fried & Williams to
properties.credit: The original footage was captured on January 17, 2014 as part of a storytelling circle called "Campfire: Eviction Ghost Stories and Other Housing Horrors." This mini-clip is part of a series of mini-clips honoring fourteen City storytellers who shared th

properties.name: Becca Gourevitch

properties.name: David Brenkus
properties.narrative: David's_Artist_Video_Final from
properties.descriptio: David Brenkus is an artist currently being Ellis Act evicted by landlords in tech, and, ironically, art curation.
properties.credit: Interview by Jin Zhu and Alexi Lacey

properties.name: Cheryl SV
properties.descriptio: "When you evict somebody, you're changing their whole lives - it's not just a place where somebody goes and sleeps." Cheryl lived in San Francisco for 30 years, and in her apartment in the Mission for 22 years before being evicted and moving to Oakland.

properties.name: Alison Roberts
properties.descriptio: Alison Roberts has lived in Fremont for 37 years, having raised four children along with grandchildren in the Mission San Jose part of town. Here she reflects on changes in Fremont, as its proximity to Silicon Valley leads to its own gentrification.

properties.name: Midtown Tenants
properties.narrative: Saving Midtown: San Francisco Renters on Strike
properties.descriptio: This is the story of the Midtown rent strike, the largest rent strike in San Francisco since 1978.

properties.name: Robert
properties.narrative: We Wont Go-HD from

properties.name: I Belong Here
properties.descriptio:
I Belong Here is a distillation of audio and stills from video interviews of young people collected by Tilt in collaboration with the Anti-Eviction Mapping Project during a workshop on June 21, 2014. 
Follow the project: #wheredoyoubelong

properties.name: Nancy Hernandez
properties.descriptio: Nancy is a non-profit worker who was born and raised in the Outer Mission, but has been forced to relocate. Nancy currently lives in Oakland.
properties.credit: Interview by Caroline Scanlon, Natasha Weiss, Jordan Carroll

properties.name: Tamikka Johnson
properties.descriptio: Tamikka Johnson is a lifelong resident of Fremont, California. She was very abruptly served with an eviction notice after the death of her elderly landlords. At the date of our interview she was uncertain of where she would be living in 60 days. She expl

properties.name: Alameda Renter's Coalition Demands Real Protections for Renters
properties.narrative: Alameda Renter's Coalition Demands Real Prote
properties.descriptio: Alameda Renter's Coalition formed as a facebook group in 2014 and has blossomed into a group of over 100 volunteers who have successfully organized to get Rent Control and Just Cause for eviction laws onto the November 2016 ballot to be voted on by their

properties.name: Jessica Bell
properties.descriptio:
Published on Jul 17, 2014
#wheredoyoubelong is a transdisciplinary, cross-platform, multi-organizational investigation into belonging, which engages artists and community members in creation, exhibition, research, and civic-engagement. #wheredoyoubelong
properties.credit:
This short video was taken at the Community Housing Partnership event on June 25 ,2014 in the Tenderloin National Forest. It was filmed by Ben Elie.

Music: Ventallation by Picou Ft. ID, BUMP Records, Copyright 2013

Video: Copyright TILT 2014.

properties.name: Oakland Creative Neighborhoods Coalition
properties.narrative: Oakland Creative Neighborhoods Coalition from
properties.descriptio:
Oakland Creative Neighborhoods Coalition
Blurb: "Over the past year, the Oakland Creative Neighborhoods Coalition has been organizing to resist the displacement of arts spaces, cultural assets, and communities of color in a rapidly gentrifying city. This

properties.name: We Are the Future: Bayanihan Youth Group Organizes Against Displacement in Alameda
properties.narrative: We Are The Future: BYG organizes against displacem
properties.descriptio: Three youth leaders of BayanihanYouth Group at Encinal High School organize their fellow students to fight for housing justice in the City of Alameda after one of the group's leaders' apartment complex received eviction notices. They share their experien

properties.name: This Place is a Root: Carla Service fights for the Malonga Performing Arts Center
properties.narrative: This Place is A Root: Carla Service fights for the
properties.descriptio: Carla Service, founder of the dance school Dance-A-Vision, housed within the Malonga, reflects on the importance of this cultural and performance space in Oakland and the fight to keep it thriving while the city prioritizes moneyed development over longs

properties.name: Karen Van Dine
properties.descriptio: Karen is a longtime resident fighting gentrification on Clay Street.

properties.name: April Squires
properties.descriptio: April Squires is a retired educator living in Alameda actively involved with the Alameda Renters Coalition. Although April's own rental unit is not eligible for rent control, April has been fighting for stronger renters' protections since learning of the

properties.name: Charlie
properties.address: Intersection of Chapin and Lincoln in Alameda
properties.narrative: Charlie - A film by Ethan Silverstein from
properties.descriptio: Charlie Edwards is a resident of Alameda and a volunteer with the Alameda Renter's Coalition, fighting for rent control and just cause eviction in the city of Alameda. In the past two years, despite his income remaining fixed, his rent has increased 33%.

properties.name: Cathy Leonard
properties.descriptio: Cathy Leonard is a third generation Oaklander living in the Sante Fe neighborhood of North Oakland. Cathy reflects on her family's longstanding history in Oakland, growing up in the constantly changing neighborhoods of North Oakland, and her own recent c

properties.name: 2044 International Boulevard
properties.narrative: 2044 International Blvd. from
properties.descriptio: A group of tenants living in an apartment building in the San Antonio district of East Oakland organize themselves to fight against the real and persistent threats of eviction from their changing landlords. Two of the lead organizers describe their build

properties.name: An interview with Fremont RISE Coalition Organizers
properties.narrative: An Interview with Fremont RISE Organizers from
properties.descriptio: In this short interview, two of Fremont RISE's organizers address the need for tenant protections in Fremont, what their organizing strategies look like, and how they define housing justice.

properties.name: Cecily Day
properties.descriptio: Cicely Day was born and grew up in Oakland. She moved away for a five years but later returned. She discusses her love and passion for Oakland and shares memories about the different phases of her life that took place in very specific sites all over city

properties.name: Hannah Raslan
properties.descriptio: Hannah is currently an undergraduate at Berkeley, living in POC house in Berkeley. She is from Whittier, California and moved with her mother and brother to Lafayette in elementary school to attend the city's public schools. She reflects on experiencing

properties.name: Jay Majitov
properties.descriptio: Jay is a housing justice organizer and tenant part of the historic Midtown Apartment fight.

properties.name: Tigray Kahsai
properties.descriptio: Tigray Kahsai is an Oakland native and daughter of two Ethiopian immigrants. She reflects on growing up in Oakland with the community that formed around her father's Ethiopian community center in West Oakland. She also reflects on the changes that gentri

properties.name: Eltyna McCree
properties.descriptio: Eltyna McCree talks about her life from childhood through today. She describes the many professions, passions, and projects she's followed throughout her life and the challenges around displacement she faced as a small business operator for over thirty f

properties.name: Hannah McDonough
properties.descriptio: Hannah is a high school student at Washington High in Fremont

properties.name: Tristen Schmidt
properties.descriptio: Tristen began by talking about where she grew up and where she lives now before transitioning into discussing the two homes she and her family were displaced from in Alameda. She had a lot to say and spoke with knowledge about eviction, displacement, and

properties.name: Rachelle Hughes
properties.descriptio: Rachelle is a student at Washington High School in Fremont, and an active member of the Anti-Eviction Mapping Project.

properties.name: Vickie Gunter and Peter Brown
properties.descriptio: Vickie Gunter and Peter Brown were active in the formation of the Oakland Cultural Affairs Commission. The interview winds arounds and there are some great stories strung throughout.

properties.name: Candace Roberts
properties.descriptio: Candace Roberts was born in Fremont, California. She came to San Francisco in 2000 for work and lived in a shared apartment in the Mission District. Her passion for singing and producing music made it hard for her to work a 9-5 job and still make enough

properties.name: Bernice Deras
properties.descriptio: Berenice is a hard working single mother who came to the US from Mexico and has worked in Fremont for 18 years. She connects with poor people’s struggle for housing, talks about class struggle with the professional class and people’s fear to speak ou

properties.name: Charles Oshinuga
properties.descriptio: Charles Oshinuga was an Oakland transplant, by way of Los Angeles, before he was evicted in 2013, and forced to move to Richmond . Charles says he grew up poor, moving around various parts of Los Angeles, until he ended up in the far inland desert stretc

properties.name: Bonnie Wills
properties.descriptio: Bonnie Wills has moved around during her life, but she's always come back to her home in West Oakland. Now, she's an old-school townie, and she's watched how its changed over the decades - who left, who stayed, who moved in, who's been pushed out. She's

properties.name: Donald French
properties.descriptio: Donald French talks about moving to Fremont in 1973, from San Diego, back when it was full of cows and fields and becoming a teacher. He also talks about how the city has changed, and how his job as a teacher influenced his views on its changing populati

properties.name: Roberta Ryan
properties.descriptio: Roberta Ryan describes living in Fremont as a Filipina immigrant, being surrounded by a vast immigrant community, of other Filipinos but also South Asians, and Asians. She talks about moving with her family and adjusting to life in the US, and then, as a

properties.name: Brendan Barthel
properties.narrative: Brendan Barthel, modern dancer from
properties.descriptio: Dancer Brendan Barthel speaks about why he came to SF and his eviction fight at 1049 Market St.

properties.name: Pauli Gray
properties.descriptio: Pauli Gray is a long-time San Francisco resident, musician, and harm reduction activist.  His former residence, fondly known as the KooKoo Faktory, was home to a rare and ever more endangered species of DIY/art/punk/weirdo solidarity and culture.  Locate

properties.name: Anti-Eviction Mapping Project
properties.narrative: Anti Eviction Mapping Project Film from
properties.descriptio: Video of the AEMP,  based out of the San Francisco Tenants Union but working throughout the region.

properties.name: Chandra Redack
properties.narrative: Chandra Redack from
properties.descriptio: Chandra Redack, an artist and musician is facing eviction with her fellow tenants and artists at 1049 Market St. They have been fighting their eviction for four years and continue to fight. This video was produced in collaboration with the San Francisco
properties.credit: The interview was shot by Alexandra Lacey and Jin Zhu of the AEMP and edited by students Anoush Mirfattah-Kahn and Chaia Startz.

properties.name: Dee Ann Newkirk
properties.descriptio: Dee Ann grew up in Kansas City. She works as an actress which brought her to Los Angeles from New York in 2004. She moved into the Beverly-Fairfax neighborhood in 2005, where she lived for 14 years. Dee Ann organized neighbors to fight their evictions, a
properties.credit:

properties.descriptio: Donna, her husband Robert Jawara Johnson, and the family dogs Xochitl (age 4) and DJ (age 2) were served with Ellis Act eviction papers in 2012, and forced out of their 73-B Pearl Street in San Francisco by serial evictors Kwok Chung Wong and Har Kwan Lu
properties.credit: The original footage was captured on January 17, 2014 as part of a storytelling circle called "Campfire: Eviction Ghost Stories and Other Housing Horrors." This mini-clip is part of a series of mini-clips honoring fourteen City storytellers who shared th

properties.name: Phyllis Bowie
properties.narrative: Phyllis Bowie from
properties.descriptio: Phyllis Bowie is facing displacement and currently part of a Rent Strike, along with her fellow tenants at Midtown Apartments in the Fillmore. An apartment complex that has history going back to the Redevelopment of the 1970's. Phyllis and the other tena
properties.credit: This video was produced in collaboration with the San Francisco Ruth Assawa School of the Arts. The interview was shot by Marianne Maeckelbergh and Brandon Jourdan and edited by students Shilo Arkinson and Avidan Novogrodsky-Godt.

properties.name: Lotta Garrity
properties.narrative: Lotta Garrity at Dearborn Community Garden fro
properties.descriptio: A San Francisco tenant speaks about her community garden and the roses which keep alive the memories of friends who have passed on.

properties.name: Diego Deleo
properties.address: 568 Chestnut St, San Francisco, CA 94133, USA
properties.narrative: Diego DeLeo from
properties.descriptio: Diego DeLeo, a poet and long time North Beach resident, faces eviction. Diego is still fighting his eviction. Please support his campaign.
properties.credit: This video was produced in collaboration with the San Francisco Ruth Assawa School of the Arts. The interview was shot by Rebecca Gourevitch of the AEMP for her amazing short 'Holding Out', with additional photography and editing by students Reign Lafran

properties.credit:

properties.name: Lois DeArmond
properties.descriptio: Lois is a lifelong resident of Los Angeles. Born in Inglewood, she has lived in Westchester and now in Mid-City. She is a retired costume designer and costume illustrator of over 30 years. As a long-time resident of Mid-City, she is here to fight the for

properties.name: Martha Lara

properties.address: 5226 Huntington Dr S, Los Angeles, CA 90032

properties.name: Katie Hoyt and Steve Clemmons

properties.narrative: M Bell pt 2 from

properties.descriptio: In this spanish interview, Gladys Puglia, a community organizer with Make the Road NY, shares her story of tenant organizing against buyouts for rent stabilized apartments for Latino and working class communities in Bushwick. Cities for People, Not for P

properties.credit: Interview by Jin Zhu; Edited by Bean Crane

properties.narrative: JOSH SHORT from
properties.descriptio: In this english interview, Joshua Carrera, a former Bushwick resident, talks about his experience growing up in Bushwick, facing eviction with his family and his involvement with MayDay, Illumination Against Gentrification, and Mi Casa No Es Su Casa. Cit

properties.name: Vanessa Perez

properties.name: Mimi Le
properties.descriptio: Mimi Le is a freelance stylist originally from Texas.  She currently resides in Silverlake where she enjoys motorcycle riding with her friends.  Mimi has been in Silverlake for seven years and loves the only neighborhood she has come to know as home in L
properties.credit:
Interviewed by Mukta Mohan

properties.descriptio: Greg and Robert received an eviction notice, their greatest fear, on the front door of the Echo Park residence Robert had called home for twenty-five years. They spoke with Terra Graziani about the dehumanizing, intrusive eviction process and their motiv
properties.credit:
Interview by Terra Graziani 

Photo by JUCO

properties.name: Charles Willis
properties.descriptio: Charles was born and raised in South Central. He was bused to school in the Valley and, as a teenager, lived through the 1992 Los Angeles Uprising. In 2006, after he was tested positive for HIV, he lost his job, faced an eviction, and lived in Skid Row f
properties.credit:

properties.name: Sally Juarez
properties.descriptio: You can see Sally driving around the streets of Eagle Rock in her stunning 1966 Chevelle Malibu. She’s been a resident of this town since 1973, which is also when she became a teacher, a profession that lasted decades until her retirement. She enjoys s
properties.credit:
Interview by Terra Graziani
Photo by JUCO

properties.name: Southwest Brooklyn Tenant Union
properties.descriptio: In this story circle, founding members of the Southwest Brooklyn Tenant Union share their collective analysis of the housing crisis in NYC, organizing strategies they have used to combat displacement, and what being part of a tenant union means to them.

properties.name: Laura Escuerdo
properties.descriptio:
Laura is a native Angeleno and resides in Silverlake with her mother. Laura is a school teacher and has a long history of empowering Latina women through activism along with mobilizing teachers for the most recent teachers strike.

Her building was a pot
properties.credit:
Interviewed by Terra Graziani

Photo by JUCO

properties.name: Mario Ceballos
properties.descriptio: Originally from Guadalajara, Mexico, Mario has lived in Silverlake for over 30 years. He loves spending time with his two dogs Paloma and Buika and often relaxes in his backyard at the Angus apartments enjoying beautiful skies. Mario has been a tenant of
properties.credit:
Interview by Jesenya Maldonado

Photo by JUCO

properties.name: Michael
properties.descriptio: Michael is a San Francisco resident who was exploited and harassed by his landlord until being forced out.
properties.credit: Interview by Caroline Scanlon, Natasha Weiss, Jordan Carroll

properties.name: Baruch Kellman
properties.descriptio: Baruch is a historic site manager for the Viviana building in DTLA and currently resides in Westlake with his dogs Chopper and Lala. He was evicted from his apartment in Echo Park a week before Christmas and opted to leave to reduce the stress level of f

properties.credit:
Interview by Mukta Mohan and Phoebe Unter

Photo by JUCO

properties.name: Zerita Jones
properties.descriptio: Zerita is a lifetime resident of the South Central Area and has never lived outside of the 405/110/105/10 freeway enclosed area.  Zerita lives with her 77-year old mother to help her with day-to-day care. She lives across the street from the high school
properties.credit:
Interview by Jesenya Maldonado and Terra Graziani

properties.name: Diana Cruz
properties.descriptio:
Of El Salvadorian descent, Diana was born in East Los Angeles and raised in Koreatown.
Diana loves her neighborhood - her little pocket of Koreatown predominantly inhabited by people of color and working class folks. However, those demographics are rapid

Photo by JUCO

properties.name: Luis Herrera

properties.credit:
Interview by Jesenya Maldonado

Photo by JUCO

properties.credit:
Interview by Mukta Mohan

properties.name: Kelley King

properties.credit:

properties.name: Nancy Torres
properties.descriptio: Nancy Torres was born and raised in Bushwick, Brooklyn. In this interview, she remembers the Bushwick of her childhood and the memories of her father working at a nearby textile factory. She discusses the entanglements of migration, labor, and housing in

properties.name: Deborah Dickerson

properties.name: Martha Ma
properties.descriptio: Martha was born and raised in Queens, NY and is currently the Farm Manager at the Bushwick Grows Community Farm, a permaculture farm and community education space.  In this interview, she describes how COVID-19 has put food insecurity on the map, and how
properties.credit: Interview by Deborah Dickerson. Tech support by Manon Vergerio.

properties.name: Samuel Nemir Olivares
properties.descriptio: In this interview, Samuel Nemir Olivares, District Leader for NY Assembly District 53 and co-founder of Bushwick Ayuda Mutua (BAM), talks about mutual aid efforts to support neighbors and fellow community members in Bushwick, Brooklyn. He reflects on his

properties.name: Kim Statuto
properties.descriptio: In this interview, Kim Statuto remembers her experience of eviction in 1994 as a single mother with four young children from her rent-controlled apartment in Manhattan, their navigation through the NYC shelter system and eventual settlement in the Bronx.

properties.name: Amy Collado
